```{R}
#1.
# create data frame
df <- data.frame(shoesize = c(6.5, 9.0, 8.5, 8.5, 10.5, 7.0, 9.5, 9.0, 13.0, 7.5, 10.5, 8.5, 12.0, 10.5, 13.0, 11.5, 8.5, 5.0, 10.0, 6.5, 7.5, 8.5, 10.5, 8.5, 10.5, 11.0, 9.0, 13.0),
                 height = c(66.0, 68.0, 64.5, 65.0, 70.0, 64.0, 70.0, 71.0, 72.0, 64.0, 74.5, 67.0, 71.0, 71.0, 77.0, 72.0, 59.0, 62.0, 72.0, 66.0, 64.0, 67.0, 73.0, 69.0, 72.0, 70.0, 69.0, 70.0),
                 gender = c("F", "F", "F", "F", "M", "F", "F", "F", "M", "F", "M", "F", "M", "M", "M", "M", "F", "F", "M", "F", "F", "M", "M", "F", "M", "M", "M", "M")
)
df
```

```{R}
#B
# subset for males
df_male <- df[df$gender=="M", c("shoesize", "height")]
df_male

# subset for females
df_female <- df[df$gender=="F", c("shoesize", "height")]
df_female
```

```{R}
#C
# mean of shoe size
mean(df$shoesize)

# mean of height
mean(df$height)
```

```{R}
#D
#There may be some relationship between shoe size and height as taller people may have larger feet. However, we cannot infer causation or a strong correlation without further analysis.
```
